title.narrative: Training Human Rights Defenders in the Law and Practice of the International Criminal Court

description.narrative: Lawyers in Guinea lack knowledge and understanding of the law and practice of the ICC; and it is difficult to get appropriate, relevant professional training.

On 28 September 2009, in Conakry, Guinea, members of the armed forces and of the security forces massacred at least 156 persons and raped more than a hundred women who participated in a peaceful demonstration. In this project ten lawyers who assist the victims of the “28 September massacre” will be trained in how to bring the persons allegedly responsible for this crime, and for other crimes against humanity in Guinea, before the International Criminal Court (ICC) in The Hague. The training will consist of two sessions. The first session (3 days) will be held in the Netherlands. The first day of the training (23 October) will be at Maastricht University. On 24 and 25 October the training will take place on the premises of the ICC in The Hague. The second session (2 days) will take place in Guinea (Conakry), in January, February or March 2020.

On 28 September 2009, in Conakry, Guinea, members of the armed forces and of the security forces massacred at least 156 persons and raped more than a hundred women who participated in a peaceful demonstration. The international fact-finding commission set up by the UN a few weeks after the massacre found that, in view of his position as the Head of State and Commander in Chief of the armed forces, the direct criminal responsibility of the former president Mousa Dadis Camara could be presumed, for the events that took place in the Stadium and during the next days. A preliminary examination by the ICC Prosecutor is at a very advanced stage of development and, if Guinea proves unwilling or unable to investigate and prosecute the persons allegedly responsible for such crimes, the potential case may end up before the ICC, pursuant to the principle of complementarity of domestic jurisdiction and the jurisdiction of the ICC underlying the ICC Statute.

The immediate target group are ten lawyers who assist the victims of the “28 September massacre” how to bring the persons allegedly responsible for this crime, and for other crimes against humanity in Guinea, before the International Criminal Court (ICC) in The Hague.

The training will consist of two sessions. The first session (3 days) will be held in the Netherlands. The first day of the training (23 October) will be at Maastricht University. On 24 and 25 October the training will take place on the premises of the ICC in The Hague. The second session (2 days) will take place in Guinea (Conakry), in January, February or March 2020.

This project will contribute to the long term impact 2 of the M&E framework - OKP - version2.0 for SROL (page 9): Citizens in Guinea are better able to access their rights through fair, efficient, impartial, independent and accountable institutions. This will be achieved through Outcome B (page 3 of the M&E framework - OKP - version2.0 for SROL ): Enhances knowledge and skills and organisations (in this case 10 lawyers who are member of the OGDH Output: 10 lawyers who assist the victims of the “28 September massacre” trained in how to bring the persons allegedly responsible for this crime, and for other crimes against humanity in Guinea, before the International Criminal Court (ICC) in The Hague.

participating-org.narrative: Organisation guinéenne de défense des droits de l’homme et du citoyen

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: International Criminal Cpurt Building in The Hague

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities. Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the Grant Obligations and Conditions, the obligatory dates for submission of the annual/additional reports are mentioned. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

In this section (maximum 1000 words), please
**For TMT+:**
Comment to what extent the outputs have been achieved. Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

actual.value: Output 1. Training in the Netherlands. The training was held according to plan. Unfortunately, of the 10 participants (5 males and 5 females) four were refused a visa (1 male and 3 females). Output 2. Training in Guinea. This training was fully achieved. -23 October 2019 training sessions at the Faculty of Law of Maastricht University: Topic Introduction to the ICC -24 and 25 2019 October training sessions at the ICC in The Hague. Topics: Day 1: Witness evidence before the ICC and Day 2: Victims participation and reparations for victims - 10 and 11 January 2020 training sessions in Guinee Conakry Topics: Day 1: The application of human rights law in the courts of Guinea and Day 2. Legal aid in the ICC +m evaluation.

title.narrative: B. Enhanced knowledge and skills of individuals and organisations (in partner countries and in the NL) in line with country/regional specific labour market needs & aiming at inclusiveness
B.I.2. % scholarship holder's /TMT participants / alumni satisfaction
B.I.8. % alumni / TMT participants who state that they have acquired new knowledge and skills; e.g. problem solving, effective communication
B.O.2. % of alumni / TMT participants who have applied the acquired knowledge and skills within their working environment
B.I.1. Number of scholarship holders / TMT participants that have successfully completed course/training (male / female / minorities)
B.O.1. Number of organisations strengthened by individual and/or group training
B.I.4. % of scholarships awarded to women
B.I.11. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the workplace

actual.value: The female participants have expanded their knowledge of international criminal law and their lawyering skills and, in so doing, they are better prepared to represent victims of human rights violations in their country, and they have increased their chances of being admitted to practice as legal professionals before the International Criminal Court.

title.narrative: B.I.10. Changes in personal, academic and professional attitudes and attributes through training and education programmes

actual.value: The participants have expanded their knowledge of international criminal law and their lawyering skills and, in so doing, they are better prepared to represent victims of human rights violations in their country, and they have increased their chances of being admitted to practice as legal professionals before the International Criminal Court. “S’agissant de l’évaluation de la formation, je serais tenté de ne pas répondre pour avoir été l’un des formateurs. Cependant , ma conception de la formation avec des professionnels , c’est un art du donner comme du recevoir , un partage d’expériences et une atmosphère propice à un enrichissement mutuel. Je puis donc attester avoir vécu une expérience extraordinaire de ponctualité , de sérieux sans se prendre au sérieux , de fraternité , de respect mutuel, les moments ont été très professionnels, l’utile et l’agréable ne faisaient qu’un. En 36 d’expérience , cette étape de Conakry aura été pour moi marquée d’une empreinte spéciale ; l’échelle de notation me paraît donc limitée et même frustrante. J’évalue donc cette formation à Très Bien Plus. Respectueusement et avec toute ma gratitude à ceux qui en ont été les acteurs directs ou indirects,
